resources:
Circadian Life
// menu bar Settings
// Title of the different screens Home Forms Information My Statistics
You belong entirely to the night you grow in the shade as a bat. You are nocturnal and you grow in the shade as an owl. You are polyvalent, as an humming-bird you grow in the night or in the day ! You are an early bird, as a tit you grow in the morning You belong entirely to the morning, as a skylark ! // TO DO : TRANSLATE // chart description Activity Graph This graph shows your average daily activity depending on the light cycles. Light cycles depend on the seasons and will have a visible impact on your activity. In the yellow part, you can see your daily activity and in the blue part your night activity. Graphique d\'activité comparatif entre jours ouvrés et jours de congé Ce graphique représente votre moyenne d\'activité les jours ouvrés comparé à celle des jours non-ouvrés, cette activité est présentée comme un cadran avec 24 heures. \n En rouge : activité les jours non-ouvrés \n En bleu : activité les jours ouvrés (de 12h00 a 23h59) Summary chart of population activity This graph shows the repartition of the average activity for the population.

Yes No at Alone In a Band Man Woman Thank You ! -- Please Select -- Select Hungry at Eat at Sport at Duration Add a moment Add Start at End at Toilettes at Pee Poo Bad Average Good Amazing Sex at Appreciation Vomiting at Birthday Child in the morning at noon in the afternoon in the evening at night 1 2 3 4 5 and more coffee Accept Decline Disclaimer Sorry You need to record data for at least one week before beig able to see your statistics, please come back later!
Introduction on circadian cycle\n\n Have you ever wonder why you are less efficient at certain moment of the day or why can you wake up before your alarm clock? Did you faced jetlag or shift work? Do you want to know when you should eat in order to stay fit?\n\n\n Since the dawn of time, the earth rotation on its axis and around the sun imposes to all living creatures daily changes and seasonal variations. These changes imply light-dark cycles, temperatures changes, and food availability or predators presence. In an evolutionary scale, all living creatures needed to anticipate those changes in order to develop an efficient survival strategy. In humans our internal clock control several behaviors, such as sleep-wake cycle, food intake, hormonal cycle, and immunity. Thus, it’s essential to understand our rhythm on a daily basis for increasing our ability to live in a healthy state. Nowadays, the field of chronobiology is evolving, and its latest developments are important in chrono-therapy (when should one take a specific drug to fight a disease more efficiently) and chrono-nutrition (when should one eat to stay in a healthy state).\n\n\n “Everything changes and nothing stands still.” Heraclitus of Ephesus (535 BC – 475 BC)\n About Us Introduction App\n\n The goal of this smartphone app is to record our activity through the phone sensors as accelerometer, light and GPS in an automatized manner. The personal data will be accessible to each user, in order to understand their own rhythm and anonymised for population scale analysis. The application has an individual progression system, you gain levels by responding to different events and hidden rewards unlocked over use.\n\n\n Goal of this project\n\n We aim at gathering data on circadian activity of people and metadata like where they live, their profession, age, weight, and more. We want to study jet lag, feeding, sleep chronotype (early birds/night owl), light entrainment (seasonal changes, effect of latitude), social entrainment, effects of drugs, such as caffeine, and sexual habits. Using these data we will be able to study our biological rhythm at a population scale.\n\n This Project is highly inspired by Till Roenneberg’s work on human chronobiology, which shed light on many aspects on our behavior, including the deleterious effect of shift work on health.\n We believe that a better knowledge of our rhythms at a population scale will be useful to improve our life quality.\n\n Jonathan Sobel, Jonathan Baeriswyl and Prof. Felix Naef have initiated this project at the Swiss institute of technology in Lausanne (EPFL).\n \n
// main activity Sun rise Sun set Ephemeris Select Interval Today Yesterday Validate Activity Interval Good Answer Bad Answer
This app allows us to collect phone sensor data, such as accelerometer, light sensor, GPS, time and atmospheric pressure in an automated way. These data will be completed using daily survey and a profile. We will use this data for a population-wide statistical analysis, which might be published in a scientific journal. These data will be anonymised and might be used in several research project involving swiss/international institutions. We will not use these data for any commercial purpose. \n\nDo you agree?
Le chronotype correspond au milieu du temps de sommeil, Les humains, comme les animaux, sont réglés sur le rythme circadien, un rythme de 24 heures. Mais chez les humains en particulier, l\'horloge interne varie d\'un individu à l\'autre, si bien que le rythme n\'est pas de 24 heures précises : chez certains, l\'horloge avance alors que chez d\'autres, elle retarde.\n Les rythmes :\n sont principalement déterminés par la lumière du soleil \n influencent le cycle d\'éveil-sommeil, les niveaux de vigilance, d\'énergie et de fatigue \n influencent également la température corporelle, les niveaux d\'hormones comme le cortical et l\'insuline.\n L\'arbitrage des rythmes circadiens est sous l\'influence :\n de facteurs génétiques \n de facteurs environnementaux \n de facteurs psychologiques.\n Les différences individuelles de rythme sont caractérisées par différents chronotypes décrivant notre comportement vis-à-vis du rythme circadien : du lève-tôt au couche-tard.
Le chronotype correspond au milieu du temps de sommeil(...)

As a single footstep will not make a path on the earth, so a single thought will not make a pathway in the mind. To make a deep physical path, we walk again and again. To make a deep mental path, we must think over and over the kind of thoughts we wish to dominate our lives. \n Henry David Thoreau // description
